page.title: 02The village of Wray
page.content: Wray may have been settled by the Norsemen.Its name means "an out of the way corner", which in some ways it still is, with its cobbles, and architecture which dates back to Tudor and Jacobean times. Wray looks like a sleepy village from the past but it lives very much for today. In August 1967, the River Roeburn flooded, tearing down bridges, walls, cottages and trees. A scattering of new houses now replaces those destroyed. The main industry is farming and only two shops remain in a village which was once alive with millworkers and traders. There is also a school, church and chapel, Institute, and two public houses.
